Bug.Summery: incorrect line terminators with windows install of ant 1.6.4
Bug.WithStack:
Files in ...\3.1.0 RC2\plugins\org.apache.ant_1.6.4\bin have unix-style line terminators (\n) instead of windows {\r\n) for a win2k install.
This causes an error when running ant (which calls ant.bat):
The system cannot find the batch label specified - end Thank you for the bug report.
We are planning to move to Ant 1.6.5 shortly and I will ensure that correct line delimiters. +1 Verified that the problem existed with our bat file.
Went through and converted the line delimiters on all of the files in org.apache.ant/bin ... then the Eclipse team support does the rest.
Thanks again Derek. Please verify DarinW. Not fixed... Michael I am at a loss on how to fix this one...thought I would ping you for some insight. I think the problem is that all SDK builds (Unix, Windows, Mac) happen on Unix and hence all the ASCII files involved end up with Unix style line feeds. Sonia, can you confirm that all builds happen on Windows? If all builds do happen on UNIX is there a way to mark a file to not have the line delimiters converted? You could make the bat file Binary. This would prevent any line-ending conversions from happening. You would need to re-commit the file in order to introduce the CRLF line endings to the file again. Thanks for the help...plan to convert to binary.
Am I correct in that after the line conversion, no outgoing changes show? Yes but when converting to Binary, I don't think the file contents are modified in any way so there wouldn't be any outgoing changes. You may need to touch the file and then commit it to change the line endings on the server. Re: comment #7, the build occurs on a single Linux box. I have converted the files to binary and have attempted to correctly release no-op changes to force the correct line delims for the various files. Testing with eclipse-sdk-n20060121-0010-win32 this appears to finally be working as expected. Thanks all. Please verify Kevin. verified

Bug.Summery: Eclipse application launch configuration file format should be platform independent
Bug.WithStack:
Right now launch configuration for an Eclipse application, when stored in a file, uses platform dependent path separator to separate plugins to be launched. This makes it impossible to share the configuration between different platforms. This problem may affect other types of launch configurations as well.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 86576 *** sorry, wrong dup.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 86796 *** I really don't think this is a duplicate of bug 86796. Bug 86796 is about string substitution variables, while this bug is not affected by these variables in any way. Note also that the workspace location parameter works exactly as expected by the user i.e. it is saved and restored from the file correctly on different platforms, so bug 86796 is simly an enhancement. On the other hand the list of plugins to be launched is not restored correctly on a different platform (resulting in an empty selection), because it assumes that both platforms use the same path separator.
Although both bugs aim to make the launch configuration more portable, I think this bug could be addressed separately by replacing File.pathSeparatorChar with a fixed character during save and replacing that fixed character with File.pathSeparatorChar during load. Please consider reopening it. oh you're right. reopening. *** Bug 99965 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Adjusting severity to major because it makes all our launch configs (that we were creating for cross platform tests) worthless. Fixed. The delimiter is now ','. We will provide backward compatibility for all existing launch configs. Great! Thanks Wassim. This ends a nightmare for all Mac developers! (and I still believe the fix was trivial...) the fix for this particular defect was indeed trivial.
However, to make your launch configurations 100% portable required more work (support for variable substitutions, etc.). It will all be in 3.2M2

Bug.Summery: [templates] java editor templates should support line number variable
Bug.WithStack:
Currently the Java Editor allows a user to customize templates: a quickly accessible snippets of text that can be dynamically populated with variables that capture the context of the editor. For example a user can type in systr and hit Ctrl-Space to autocomplete which will create a System.out.println() call with the text of the current method in the editor.
It would be very helpful if a line number variable was added to the list of the variables already available: it would greatly simplify addition of logging statements to existing code. Those line numbers would be outdated very quickly. There are currently no plans to add this. Get rid of deprecated state.

Bug.Summery: ModelingBeanInfo.stripList() should not reuse FeatureDescriptorEquality classes.
Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.jem.internal.beaninfo.vm.ModelingBeanInfo.stripList() should not reuse the FeatureDescriptorEquality classes because this can lead to a ClassCastException in IndexedPropertyDescriptorEquality.
If the first property of a list is a indexed property, the , this leads to a ClassCastException in IndexedPropertyFeatureEquality if the property compared is not an indexed property. Sorry, accidently commited too early.
The ClassCastException happens in the IndexedPropertyDescriptorEquality.equals.
We can get indexed properties in our list because we collect all properties with introspection In our base bean info class. We configure them (set to hidden/expert, add enumeration values etc.) in the concrete bean info classes. In one class now it happens to be the case that the first property found is an indexed property, so the FeatureDescriptorEquality class used as a working copy for the full list is an IndexedPropertyDescriptorEquality.
After the ClassCastException the whole BeanInfo is not read which leads to missing properties in the Property Sheet.
I don't want to keep recreating the working copies. What I should do is instead have only IndexedPropertyFeatureEquality and have it understand that it may wrapper only a Property and not an Indexed property.
Thanks for bring this to my attention. The fix has been released to HEAD. VE 1.1 is released. Moving to closed.

Bug.Summery: [breakpoints] Breakpoints dropped to incorrect working set when moved using drag and drop

Lines.Line: 1. Create 3 Breakpoints Working Sets (e.g. Working Set A/B/C)
2. Add a few breakpoints in each of the working sets
3. Drag a breakpoint from Working Set A to Working Set B and drop it between
the last breakpoint of Working B and the beginning of Working Set C.

Bug.WithStack:
1. Create 3 Breakpoints Working Sets (e.g. Working Set A/B/C) 2. Add a few breakpoints in each of the working sets 3. Drag a breakpoint from Working Set A to Working Set B and drop it between the last breakpoint of Working B and the beginning of Working Set C.
e.g. Working Set A * breakpoint 1 * breakpoint 2 Working Set B * breakpoint 3 Working Set C * breakpoint 4
- drag breakpoint 2 and drop it between breakpoint 3 and Working Set C.
Result: Breakpoint 2 is grouped under Working Set C.
Expected Result: Breakpoint 2 should be grouped under Working Set B since it was dropped under Working Set B.
Similarly, if you move Breakpoint 2 from Working Set C, and put it between Breakpoint 3 and Working Set C again, the breakpoint will not move. This may be a drag & drop bug - the mouse has to be over group C for this to happen, althought the "drop line" is shown before group C. Deferred open for 3.3 fixed with fix to 104369
see BreakpointDropAdapter, BreakpointDragAdapter, BreakpointsView, BreakpointsViewer please verify Darin W Verified.

Bug.Summery: [implementation] AbstractTextEditor should not call setInput(null)
Bug.WithStack:

AbstractTextEditor calls setInput(null) in its dispose method. This is a violation of the specification for that method, and leads to a violation of IEditorPart.getEditorInput() as well.

subComponent="./framework/RAServerConfig/RAServerConfigBinding2.cpp" componentType="Eclipse_TPTP"/> <situation categoryName="ReportSituation"> <situationType xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema- instance" xsi:type="ReportSituation" reasoningScope="INTERNAL" reportCategory="LOG"/> </situation> </CommonBaseEvent>
This problem is caused by the XML encoding of the pluginconfig.xml file of org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.jmxagent plugin. It is UTF-8. However, the file is in EBCDIC encoding so the XML encoding string in the file must be an EBCDIC codepage, for example ibm-1047-s390.
Either the XML encoding string in the file must be changed or if this plugin is not supported on z/OS, then the org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.jmxagent plugin should not be included in the Agent Controller packaging for z/OS.
The driver this problem was found in was TPTP 3.3.0_20050613_0754. I checked a fix into 4.0 for this, and, as it was not marked critical or blocking by kent I wasn't able to get the fix into the 3.3 build. The fix was to no longer use a static pluginconfig but to generate one using the rac plugin extensions.
I have thought about this, and as far as I can tell, JOnAS and JBoss (although I have not fully investigated the latter) are not servers that have full Z/OS support. There is no reason why they cannot be made to run though.
I don't feel overly confident in checking any changes into 3.3, and in the light that the server are not support I think it would be best if the agent support was removed for z/OS.
Does that sound reasonable to you? I am marking this as a duplicate of Kent's bug 94594. This got moved to TPTP 4.0 as per request on a platform call, and was subsequently fixed in 4.0.

Bug.Summery: [CCombo] Very long text in CCombo causes vertical scroll bar to disappear

Lines.Line: 1) The SWT.H_SCROLL style-bit was not being set for the List in CCombo.
Patch fixes this by setting the SWT.H_SCROLL for the list by default. The user cannot set or unset this style-bit for CCombo (similar to Combo).

2) The size of combo is computed based on the size of the list and so that it fits into the screen. When user selects the drop-down list, the size of the list is computed again and its width is set to max of list width and combo width. So, for long text, the list goes out of the screen and the horizontal scroll-bar is not shown.
Patch fixes this by setting the width of the pop-up list equal to the Combo width. Now, the pop-up list will not show-up wider than the Combo. Also, horizontal scroll-bar will show-up when required.
This is good, but when the CCombo's width is set small, then the list is too small, and it does not have to be.
1)The list appears without scroll-bar if its width less than "max width".
2)Horizontal scroll-bar is shown only when list width is greater than combo width and "max width".
3)"max width" is computed based on the monitor width.
4)Combo width is used for list width if it is bigger than the list width.
Modified the patch to compute the drop-down list of CCombo similarly.

Bug.Summery: [typing] Moving first line of header comment increases indentation
Bug.WithStack:
Given a class like this:
/** * Header comment */
class Foo { }
Put the cursor on the first line, and use Alt+Down, Alt+Up to move it down, and then up. An extra space is added in front. If you now select the entire file and use Source > Indent, the whole file is shifted one character to the right. Tom, please investigate. This uses to work and looks like a regression added by the recent changes. Also broken for traditional comment. 3.1 RC3 candidate. Created attachment 23046 JavaIndenter.diff
Patch for JavaIndenter.java - if the start of the file is reached while backwards scanning, we should return NOT_FOUND instead of zero as the reference location. Approving for 3.1 RC3.
Dirk, this is a regression that has been introduced with RC2. Can you approve? +1. fixed > 20050615 please investigate. Created attachment 23277 99725.diff
Patch against jdt-ui.
In order to fix bug 97474, which was really the same issue as bug 98060, we decided to only shift lines on move, instead of properly indenting the same way IndentAction does, causing this problem and also bug 100219.
The proposed patch reverts back to indenting (as opposed to shifting) in JavaMoveLinesAction, and applies the same changes that fixed bug 98060 to IndentUtil: instead of abusing the javadoc autoindenter, we compute the indent ourselves for multi-line comment partitions. Bug.Summery: Problem with invalid server/runtime combination in Web Service wizard
Bug.WithStack:
I have been trying to add a server and a runtime for WTP Web Services wizard. I added a server 'MyServer'.
After doing this I did the following- Created a new 'J2EE Web Project'. Set the default server to 'MyServer' Created a new Web Service. Select 'Java Bean web service'. Click Finish.
Now the runtime used is Axis while the server used is 'MyServer'. Even though this combination of server-runtime-type is invalid still it is taken as default. This obviously causes problems. If I go up to the 3rd page of the wizard then an error is displayed saying that the project runtime and selected one doesn't match and at this point the 'Next' and 'Finish' buttons are disabled. I dont think this makes sense i.e. allowing to complete the creation process on the first page itself while when on 3rd page its not allowed. I logically fail to understand how a process can be completed initially using some (wrong) default values but if I go ahead then at some later point when the wrong combination is detected then in that case I cant proceed.
I feel WTP should verify this server-runtime-type combination when I click finish and display and error or disable the Finish button on the first screen.
Looks to be like theres a bug/flaw in WTP. This is a bug. The wizard should always choose a viable default server/RT configuration (when one exists) over a non-viable one. Bug.Summery: [arch] WSDL Validation mixes UI and Model (core) function
Bug.WithStack:
The model vs. UI functionality should be cleaningly split so "model" features/plugins can be correctly componentized independent from UI components.
I've marked this as "major" since I think this is a flaw that prevents correct features/components from being defined. As it is now, wsdl would have to be included in UI featues .. which I don't think is the intent. David, I think this can be solved by leaving the WSDL validator along with the ant and command line UI's in the org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.validation plugin and moving the Eclipse UI specific code to org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.ui.
Will this work for you? Yes, If I'm looking at it right, that would allow both org.eclipse.ui org.eclipse.wst.xml.validation to be removed from pre-reqs.

Bug.Summery: [build path] Exclusion filters are added on new source folder when unnecessary
Bug.WithStack:
In RC2.
If you add a source folder inside another source folder, the outer folder's exclusion filters are updated to avoid ambiguity. Now, remove the inner folder from the class path, and re-add it. Every time this is done, the inner folder is added to the outer folder's exclusion filter, ad infinitum. David, how did you add the source folder.
Martin, IMO not critical. Speak up if you think different. In the build path dialog, using the "Add Folder..." button. I just realized that the problem is more that the automatic exclusion is not removed when the source folder is removed: this means that if I accidentally add "org" as a source folder under "src", and then realize my mistake and remove "org" from the class path, I am left with no class files, because the exclusion on org remains. I agree that we should automatically remove the exclusions that we added.
In fact, the best thing would be if jdt.core does an automatic exclusion of nested source folders. fixed > 20051220
Exclusion/Inclusion filters are removed in other source folders if a source folder is removed.

Bug.Summery: Unable to add module to Geronimo server

Lines.Line: - this problem is caused by an NPE
- which is caused because the GenericServerRuntime.getServerDefinitionId() is null
- which is because GenericServerRuntime.setServerDefinitionId() is never called
- which is because that method is (as far as I can tell) only invoked in one
place.
- there is a runtime retrieved from task model(sth like 98098)
- enter for wizard fragment is called
- the default values are validated OK
Changed Version field given new release numbering.

Bug.WithStack:
Driver: 0613N
In a new workspace, install the Geronimo 1.0 server and then create a Web module targeting Geronimo 1.0. After creating a Geronimo server, I right-click on ther server to "Add project to server". However, the Web module created does not show up on the left-hand side as available module to add.
If I then install Tomcat 5.0 and create a Tomcat 5.0 targetting module, both the Geronimo and Tomcat module are availabe to be added to a Tomcat 5.0 server. If I go back to try to add module to the Geronimo server, both the Geronimo and Tomcat modules are available as well. Gorkem, - this problem is caused by an NPE - which is caused because the GenericServerRuntime.getServerDefinitionId() is null - which is because GenericServerRuntime.setServerDefinitionId() is never called - which is because that method is (as far as I can tell) only invoked in one place.
The id is actually set (only) in ServerTypeDefinitionRuntimeDecorator.validate().
Ignoring the question of whether a validate() method is the right place to save data, this method is only invoked (as far as I can tell) in the ServerTypeDefinitionDecorator.PathModifyListener.modifyText() method.
Unwinding all that, it means that if the user enters any changes in the path field, the data is saved and all works (Kathy, you can use this as a workaround). However, the Geronimo adapter uses reasonable defaults for these fields, so people do not always need to make any changes to the text. In that case, the modifyText method is never call, the validate is then not called, the id is not set... and I get an NPE later on.
I believe the best fix would be to move the following setup methods from ServerTypeDefinitionRuntimeDecorator.validate(), and into a method that must be called on exit of the page.
fRuntime.setServerDefinitionId(fRuntime.getRuntime().getRuntimeType().getId()); fRuntime.setServerInstanceProperties(getValues()); fRuntime.getRuntimeWorkingCopy().setLocation(new Path(wDir));
A simpler solution may just be to force the validate method to be invoked more robustly.
Tim you are right the name validate is confusing, I should change it to someting more explaining validateAndSet(). But I could not reproduce this and I am not sure this is a case of validate not being called for defaults because validate for all decorators are called in the enter() of wizard fragments. As a result the default values for a runtime should be set if - there is a runtime retrieved from task model(sth like 98098) - enter for wizard fragment is called - the default values are validated OK Changed Version field given new release numbering.
I could not reproduce with generic jboss server. I can reproduce this problem. I'm still trying to figure out the cause, but the behavior is that the server runtime is being partially created. Then the GenericServerRuntime.getServerDefinitionId() returns null, which results in the NPE.
You are correct that the validate method is being called, I have traced through that now... but I can't figure out why the data is not correct. To reproduce this problem, you need to delete all the installed server runtimes (from the preferences dialog) - for some reason (as Kathy noted), even the existance of another runtime is enough to get the code working.
The most detail I've observed so far is looking at the servers.xml (in the .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core directory). When the file is created as the only server (ie, in the bad case), here's the file: <server server-type-id="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" runtime-id="Apache Geronimo v1.0" hostname="localhost" name="Apache Geronimo 1.0(Generic)" id="6_15_05_4_27_PM4" server-type="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" />
When the file is created after I've created a Tomcat server (ie, delete everything, create Tomcat, then create the new server) (this is the working case), here's what I see:
<server server-type-id="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" runtime-id="Apache Geronimo v1.0(Generic)" hostname="localhost" name="Apache Geronimo 1.0(Generic)" id="6_15_05_4_27_PM4" server-type="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" />
Notice the runtime-id - in the second scenario, it includes (Generic), but in the first case, it does not.
This is only a half-done investigation, and therefore a half-baked theory - but what I'm exploring is whether some piece of code (mine or yours) is (or should be) appending this string to the id. Subsequent usages of the data therefore fail because it's missing the (Generic) tag - and that results in the null ID and subsequent NPE.
Either way, this is a valid defect, so please reactivate it - pass the ownership over to me if you wish, as I'm quite willing to believe (now) that the problem is in my code somewhere.... Reopened Tim, I could not reproduce this one using I0623 but I was not able to reproduce before that either. I am transfering it to you since I can not progress. I can no longer reproduce this, using eclipse 3.1 & the WTP 6/30 build. If you still see the problem, please reopen the bug. Using Eclipse 3.1 with WTP0.7RC1, I am able to see the geronimo-targetted projects and add them to Geronimo server. However, if I right-click on a Geronimo or Tomcat server and select "Add or remove project", I can add projects regardless of whether them are targetted to Tomcat and Geronimo. Is this supposed to be the case or should only the project targetted to a specific server be visible? Hi Kathy,
That is the correct behaviour - we never use a runtime target to filter or restrict where the user can deploy an application. It is equivalent to the JDT, where you can compile against one JRE and run on a different one, or even multiple different ones.
Although targetting a project to a specific runtime may allow the user to use some runtime-specific features, we have no way of knowing that this is the case. They may also have targetted to a generic J2EE library or a previous version of a runtime, which would allow the app to run fine. In the end, it is the user's decision (and choice of risk) if they want to compile and run against different runtimes. Problem fixed in WTP0.7RC1. Closing.

When the file is created after I've created a Tomcat server (ie, delete everything, create Tomcat, then create the new server) (this is the working case), here's what I see:
<server server-type-id="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" runtime-id="Apache Geronimo v1.0(Generic)" hostname="localhost" name="Apache Geronimo 1.0(Generic)" id="6_15_05_4_27_PM4" server-type="org.eclipse.jst.server.geronimo.10" />
Notice the runtime-id - in the second scenario, it includes (Generic), but in the first case, it does not.
This is only a half-done investigation, and therefore a half-baked theory - but what I'm exploring is whether some piece of code (mine or yours) is (or should be) appending this string to the id. Subsequent usages of the data therefore fail because it's missing the (Generic) tag - and that results in the null ID and subsequent NPE.
Either way, this is a valid defect, so please reactivate it - pass the ownership over to me if you wish, as I'm quite willing to believe (now) that the problem is in my code somewhere.... Reopened Tim, I could not reproduce this one using I0623 but I was not able to reproduce before that either. I am transfering it to you since I can not progress. I can no longer reproduce this, using eclipse 3.1 & the WTP 6/30 build. If you still see the problem, please reopen the bug. Using Eclipse 3.1 with WTP0.7RC1, I am able to see the geronimo-targetted projects and add them to Geronimo server. However, if I right-click on a Geronimo or Tomcat server and select "Add or remove project", I can add projects regardless of whether them are targetted to Tomcat and Geronimo. Is this supposed to be the case or should only the project targetted to a specific server be visible? Hi Kathy,
That is the correct behaviour - we never use a runtime target to filter or restrict where the user can deploy an application. It is equivalent to the JDT, where you can compile against one JRE and run on a different one, or even multiple different ones.
Although targetting a project to a specific runtime may allow the user to use some runtime-specific features, we have no way of knowing that this is the case. They may also have targetted to a generic J2EE library or a previous version of a runtime, which would allow the app to run fine. In the end, it is the user's decision (and choice of risk) if they want to compile and run against different runtimes. Problem fixed in WTP0.7RC1. Closing.

Bug.Summery: (Plat) JVMPI Agent cannot connect to RAC when workbench on a remote terminal session

Lines.Line: - Start RAC as a Windows System Service, started at boot time (Standard Usage),
on a machine supporting the Windows Terminal Server.
- Log in from a remote terminal
- Start Workbench from the remote terminal (Note 1)
- Start Profiling an application on the same machine.
Note 1: on a machine configured for quick user switching, workbench may also be
started from any other named terminal session.

Bug.WithStack:
- Start RAC as a Windows System Service, started at boot time (Standard Usage), on a machine supporting the Windows Terminal Server. - Log in from a remote terminal - Start Workbench from the remote terminal (Note 1) - Start Profiling an application on the same machine. Note 1: on a machine configured for quick user switching, workbench may also be started from any other named terminal session.
You get the error message: "IWAT0004W Problems occurred while launching the Java Process. Reason: Profiler unable to establish connection with RAC. Possible fix: Add more memory or reduce dataChannelSize in serviceconfig.xml."
The problem turns out to be a mismatch in the namespace for named objects. The RAC, started as described above, causes all of its named objects to be created in the global namespace. The shared memory between the RAC and piAgent is one such named object.
The Workbench (and the SUT) when started by a user logged in from a remote terminal or on a machine configured for quick user switching, from a differently named terminal session, creates all named objects prefixed with the session name.
The end result of this mismatch in the namespaces for the RAC and the SUT is that the SUT cannot locate the shared memory object created by the RAC.
The object names for the shared memory as reported by procExp are: RAService.exe \BaseNamedObjects\OSSMEMrabuffer0 java.exe \Sessions\12\BaseNamedObjects\OSSMEMrabuffer0 (In ProcExp, select the process and do a Find -> Find Handle...)
How to fix: All named objects, both in the RAC and in the Workbench should be created in the Global namespace. This may be achieved by adding the "Global\" prefix to all named object at creation time. For example,
CreateFileMapping(.,Global\MySharedMemory);
The default is local or session namespace. Note that this change should be implemented for all shared named objects on both RAC and Workbench sides. I am assigning this to Samson for RAC. Hoang is copied for new agent controller. Transferring all normal-P3 bugs to 4.2 Transfer all normal severity bugs to 4.3 *** Bug 103230 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fix checked in 04/25/2006. File affected ossipcmemory.cpp. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. Bug.WithStack:
You aren't required to specify implicit dependencies in plugin.xml (or manifest.mf). PDE figures them out and sets the expanded dependencies in your Build Path. But when you do a Build/Build All in the update .site editor for a site that specifies a plug-in project that builds fine in Eclipse, the same project has build errors, apparently due to the implied dependencies.
From his comment in the newsgroup, apparently Pascal thinks that the dependency expansion done automatically or by Compute Classpath is not a feature and that you have to explicitly specify all dependencies. a) This isn't the way it works and b) if it were, it would be horrible; it would be impossible to specify the dependencies in a platform-independent way.
Another user commented: This is bug, probably.There are more example emf,gef,ve,webtools - all build in workspace, but export for deployment doesn't work Could you give steps on how to reproduce? Apparently, you can just install GEF as a source project and try it.
But, for example, I have a project with an explicit dependency on org.eclipse.jface.text but no explicit dependency on org.eclipse.jface. The Build Path computed by PDE includes org.eclipse.jface.
If I try to do, e.g., an update build from this project, any references to org.eclipse.jface packages are compile errors. The Build Path also contains a dependency on org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86 when there is only an explicit dependency on org.eclipse.swt. I didn't start with this example because it may be special-cased, but it is a fairly key feature.
PS I'm still trying to figure out how to do n platform-dependent builds from one "manifest". Example of such an error in a project that compiles without error in Eclipse using a PDE-generated build path:
# 13 Jun 2005 12:21:32 ---------- 1. ERROR in D:\eclipse3.1RC2\eclipse\workspace\com.objfac.xmleditor.manifested\src\com\objfac\rnceditor\RNCActionContributor.java (at line 8) import org.eclipse.jface.action.IMenuManager; ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The import org.eclipse.jface cannot be resolved
(Sorry to trickle this out. It took me awhile to get a project set up to reproduce the problem.) I do apologize for spamming, but this error is probably a better example as it illustrates the issue with specifying a platform-independent manifest. The manifest refers to org.eclipse.swt, but the build:
52. ERROR in D:\eclipse3.1RC2\eclipse\workspace\com.objfac.xmleditor.manifested\src\com\objfac\rnceditor\RNCCompletionProposal.java (at line 13) import org.eclipse.swt.custom.StyledText; ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The import org.eclipse.swt cannot be resolved
I'm rather surprised that _any_ project builds. Do you have projects loaded as linked folder in your workspace? No, all projects are physically in the workspace folder. I got GEF from HEAD of the repository and exported it and everything worked fine. Please build me a reproduceable test case from a fresh workspace. Can I shine your shoes while I'm up? ;-}
You could try to make your own example, you know. I described what to do pretty clearly. The GEF thing was some other user's experience, not mine. Today I spent my day building various projects and RCP app without problems. If I'm asking it is because I can't reproduce...
Fair enough.
Looking back, I may have answered one of your questions incorrectly. I said no to linked project folders because I'm not conscious of them as linked folders. Apparently linked project folders don't show the decoration that user-defined linked folders in projects do. But yes I have every SDK plugin in my workspace as a linked folder. And you're right, it's hard to reproduce this problem unless you do.

Bug.Summery: [Forms] [Regression] Border painting no longer working for TableTree
Bug.WithStack:
TableTree was deprecated during one of the 3.1Milestone levels. When that happened, the border-painting code in FormToolkit was changed. It used to say in one part: else if (inactiveBorder || c instanceof Table || c instanceof Tree || c instanceof TableTree) { ... code to paint the border
After TableTree was deprecated, the "c instanceof TableTree" was removed in the above clause. The result is that TableTrees no longer have their border painted. This is a problem. We can't switch to the replacement for TableTrees without pre-reqing level 3.1 of Eclipse. But our code needs to run on 3.0 levels as well.
Please restore the painting of borders for TableTrees, even though it is deprecated. RC3 candidate.
We will restore the support by adding TableTree back in the 'or' clause. Risk: slim to none. We had that code before. Mazen, can you serve as approver for this bug? sounds like a safe fix. reverting to tested code. you have my blessings! :)
Created attachment 23089 The released fix. Fixed.

On a side note, why isn't the preferences index hierarchical? This would makes sense to me since that is how the preference pages themselves are organized.

Bug.Summery: Need URIResolverExtension for Flexible Projects
Bug.WithStack: Chuck has OK'd adding commonu.uriresolver as a dependency for common.modulecore so the extension can be supplied by that plugin. Created org.eclipse.wst.common.componentcore.internal.util.ComponentResolver and committed to HEAD. It is associated with projects having the org.eclipse.wst.common.modulecore.ModuleCoreNature nature only. There's a flaw in resolving references not beginning with "/" when the reference itself is absolute. Should check if the given system reference is a file on the filesystem and return null if so. Updated ComponentResolver committed to HEAD. Verified in 0.7M5

Bug.Summery: [arch] ValidationPlugin should not extend WTPPlugin
Bug.WithStack:
This is an unneccesary dependancy that complicates the life of all that want to extend/implement validation. Seems only reason its done this way is for some common "utility" functions like logging, which should be re-implemented in validation code itself.
wst.validation framework needs to be very light weight.
I marked as major since this complicates whole dependancy tree, and is preventing other plugin consolidataion. It is the same issue as 99797: org.eclipse.wst.validation should not depend on JEM and I have added my comments to 997967

Bug.Summery: [arch] need for IHeadlessRunnableWithProgress.java is unclear
Bug.WithStack:
I do not see any reason for IHeadlessRunnableWithProgress.java. Doesn't the org.eclispe runtime interfaces suffice for run(IProgressMonitor) ? The problem with using IRunnableWithProgress is that that interface is in the org.eclipse.jface plugin, which pulls in UI plugins. IHeadlessRunnableWithProgress is identical, but does not cause us to prereq UI plugins in our non-UI plugins... hence the naming convention with "Headless".
I am going to close this as WONTFIX, but if you so desire, we could reopen this and ask that IRunnableWithProgress be moved down to a non-UI plugin in base Eclipse.

Bug.Summery: Empty webservices.xml file generated with validation errors.

Lines.Line: 1) Create a Flexible project with one module in a blank workspace.
2) Open the J2EE perspective.
3) In the Project Explorer view expand the Web Services entry in the tree.
4) Then expand the Services folder and the Client folder. At this point the
empty webservices.xml file is generated and the validation is kicked off.

Bug.WithStack:
On the 20050608 build I ran into a problem where the Project Explorer in the J2EE perspective created an empty webservices.xml file. Automatic validation of this new file started and generated an error. Here is what the details of the validation error message said:
The errors below were detected when validating the file "j2ee_web_services_1_1.xsd" via the file "webservices.xml". In most cases these errors can be detected by validating "j2ee_web_services_1_1.xsd" directly. However it is possible that errors will only occur when j2ee_web_services_1_1.xsd is validated in the context of webservices.xml.
White spaces are required between publicId and systemId.
To reproduce this problem perform the following: 1) Create a Flexible project with one module in a blank workspace. 2) Open the J2EE perspective. 3) In the Project Explorer view expand the Web Services entry in the tree. 4) Then expand the Services folder and the Client folder. At this point the empty webservices.xml file is generated and the validation is kicked off.
It seems a bit odd that a deployment descriptor would be generated just by viewing the Project Explorer. However, I could live with this as long as there was no validation error generated. This is fixed for the 0627 WTP I build. Verified that this is fixed in the I20050628 driver. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: [WorkbenchParts] Only show recursive creation errors when debugging
Bug.WithStack:
See bug 99513
The recursive part creation warning could be omitted with no ill-effects. This enhancement suggests only logging the exception when in debug mode.
I'm filing this bug for discussion because some clients find the warning annoying. However, I'm not sure this is a good idea. Most clients are unaware that creating cyclic dependancies between views is a bug, and they find the warning annoying because they believe the bug is in the workbench - not their own code. The likely result of omitting the warning is that the bugs will remain undetected and unfixed. Suggest closing this as WONTFIX. There are currently no plans to work on this feature.

I'm filing this bug for discussion because some clients find the warning annoying. However, I'm not sure this is a good idea. PW

Bug.Summery: Should rcp app template contain a product file
Bug.WithStack:
3.1RC2 On creation of a new rcp app, none of the example contains a product file. I'm not sure why it is the case, but one sure thing is that it makes very little sense for a user which for the first time of its life wants to try the coolness of RCP.
I'm marking as major not only to get Wassim's attention, but because I think it is unfortunate that such a tremendous effort has been spent on making RCP easy to use, but we are missing this little thing that would complete the story. This is a good idea for an ENHANCEMENT.
It is actually not that easy to implement. Generating a pre-canned product file with the template is actually a lot of work and complex and not portable.
However, with the recent addition of the option to add branding to all the rcp templates and the context-sensitivity of the Product configuration wizard, dreating a product configuration after-the-fact becomes trivial.

does not go away.

Bug.Summery: [URI resolver] ExtensibleURIResolver doesn't respect "/" for files in the workspace

Lines.Line: 1) 'platform:/resource/foo/main.html'.
2) 'file:///D:/myworkspace-location/foo/main.html'

Bug.WithStack:
When no prenormalization extensions are defined for the ExtensibleURIResolver, URIs beginning "/" go through normalization and end up using the root of the filesystem as the definition of "/", even though files in the workspace should use the workspace root or project folder as "/". Resolution of web pages in the webtools web site that point to "/main.html" end up going to "d:/main.html" instead of "d:/eclipse/workspace/webtools/main.html". Created attachment 22955 Patch to ExtensibleURIResolver.java to respect "/"
Treats URIs beginning with "/" differently when an in-workspace file has been calculated. Created attachment 22972 updated patch
Attached new patch that only normalizes with project as root if no prenormalization result was obtained Routing for Craig for review/comment. Are you saying that in general, for all artifacts in the workspace we should resolve the leading '/' to be workspace relative instead of file system relative? Or does this only apply only in the context of web projects?
If the former, then we'll need to have a larger discussion on this.
If the latter, and it's just the case that web projects want to use special 'mapping rules' that must apply before the URI is normalized, then I'd suggest registering a 'prenormalization' resolver extension that knows how to expand the leading slash accordingly (e.g. '/foo/main.html' --> file:///D:/eclipse/workspace/foo/main.html'). Yes, I do mean the former and not specifically for web projects (web/flexible projects have their own semantics which is why the patch only has an effect after prenormalization extensions have been given a chance to run). The resolution of resources from inside of the workspace should respect the sandboxing that the workspace represents and resolve "/" as inside of the workspace. Does it really make sense for an XML file referring to the system ID "/foo.dtd" require that every user place foo.dtd in the root of their workspace's drive? On Win32 this is merely silly but in a multi-user Unix environment it might be impossible. Thanks for clarifying Nitin. I agree that it would be a nice convenience to be able to specify workspace relative resources as '/foo/main.html' with the assumption that if a user ever wanted to specify the root of his Unix file system they'd specify 'file:///foo/main.html'. The default EMF behaviour uses the same convention, so I agree we should add this to the 'base' resolution behaviour.
How do you think we should expand the '/foo/main.html'? AFAIK we have 2 choices here
1) 'platform:/resource/foo/main.html'. 2) 'file:///D:/myworkspace-location/foo/main.html'
In the vast majority of cases it won't make a difference. But if resources contain relative URI's (e.g. '../../blah/foo.xsd') that 'back out' of a project then (1) would enable '..' to cross projects and (2) would enable '..' to go outside of the workspace. The EMF behaviour uses option (1). I'd suggest we do the same.
Nitin, I'm a little confused. I thought from the description that "/" indicated the workspace root but your patch seems to interpret "/" as the containing project folder. Can you clarify? Yes, my intent with the patch is to use the project itself as the "root". I'm not sure how to solve the cross-project reference issue, but I think lookups should otehrwise be jailed into the conceptual root: "../../../" from workspace/project/1 should only go up to workspace/project and never go outside the workspace. When considering the workspace vs. project as root issue, cross-project mappings would best be handled by a separate URI resolver extension, since every project nature might treat them differently. Some natures would forbid it while others might allow it with specially formed URIs. I'd like to defer this bug until after 0.7 since I think we need to think this thru carefully before making any changes this late in the release.

Bug.Summery: Export product blows away existing build.xml

Lines.Line: - right click on plugin.xml, and generate the build script
- add in the build.properties, custom=true (which will indicate pde build to not
overwrite the script)
- add your own targets to the generated build.xml and you are done.
- gather.bin.parts
- build.jars (and the targets used to build individual jars)
Isn't that bug directly related to bug 82302?
In the other bug it is requested that pde generates a file with another name
than build.xml, because people don't want to put custom=true in their
build.properties in order not to loose the content of their file. If your
request is the same then close this bug as dup of the other.
Yeah, I agree that bug 82302 is a duplicate. I've added a reference back to
this one because I think this one clarifies that not everyone is dealing with a
clean world of plugins only.

Bug.WithStack:
We have a couple of plugins which aren't really plugins, in that they are really non-PDE projects that we have converted to plugins so that an RCP project can use them. The problem is that the other non-RCP main development stream relies on the use of build.xml files, but unfortunately exporting our Eclipse product blows away those build.xml files(with RC1), and we have to be careful not to check in the deletion. I would like to ask that PDE use a different build file name that is guaranteed to be a unique temporary file name so that it won't overwrite our existing build.xml files. I notice that https://bugs.eclipse. org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=87729 essentially addresses the same problem, although they were looking for the build.xml to be written to an entirely different directory. Although marked as such, that bug is NOT a true duplication of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=85013. Whatever worked in those cases could maybe be used for this issue? If those plugins are not real plugins, then I recommend you the following approach to do only once: - right click on plugin.xml, and generate the build script - add in the build.properties, custom=true (which will indicate pde build to not overwrite the script) - add your own targets to the generated build.xml and you are done.
Thanks Pascal - I looked at the generated build.xml file, and noted that our own build.xml gets almost all its targets through an import tag and that several of our target names conflict with those of PDE's generated targets, and then I lost my motivation to figure out how to do this! In the meantime I'll live with having to do CVS Override and Update of our own build.xml files after I export my RCP product.
Now while I'm here, let me see if I've figured out how to link to bugs better: in my initial report I was trying to say that this issue is similar to those of bug 87729 and bug 85013. Of all the targets, the only ones that are used by pde build on product exports are: - gather.bin.parts - build.jars (and the targets used to build individual jars) Isn't that bug directly related to bug 82302? In the other bug it is requested that pde generates a file with another name than build.xml, because people don't want to put custom=true in their build.properties in order not to loose the content of their file. If your request is the same then close this bug as dup of the other. Yeah, I agree that bug 82302 is a duplicate. I've added a reference back to this one because I think this one clarifies that not everyone is dealing with a clean world of plugins only.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 82302 ***

Bug.Summery: [Polish] RAServer gets SEGV on shutdown on RHEL 3.0 upd 4
Bug.WithStack:
If you start RAServer on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 3.0 update 4, when you bring it down with RAStop.sh (or just with kill) it crashes with the following console output:
JVMDG217: Dump Handler is Processing Signal 11 - Please Wait. JVMDG303: JVM Requesting Java core file
The same problem does not occur on SLES 9. The JRE is an IBM 1.4.2 JRE:
J2RE 1.4.2 IBM build cxia32142-20050411
It appears that the culprit may be the file transfer service. If you stomp on serviceconfig.xml to set the "jvm" attribute of AgentControllerConfiguration to an empty string (and thereby prevent the file transfer service from starting), the crash goes away. Created attachment 22959 Java core dump from crash (Unix text file)
This is the dump created by the crash. Dunno if it is of any use or not. Scott, can you take a look? Thanks.
I am also seeing this in Windows as well using the IBM JRE 1.4.2 -- it does not show up in 3.3 though, I'm investigating. Not all the code has been migrated from 3.3 into 4.0 for the file transfer service but I would still not expect to see such a nasty crash to occur. Sorry, in my haste to go to lunch (never let a hungry developer file a bug :-), I forgot some details:
I reproduced this with the v3.3 20050613_0754 dev build. We originally noticed it with a 6/8 build. I'm pretty sure we were *not* seeing it with a build from around 6/1 or 6/2...sorry, I don't remember the precise archaeology. In any case, it looks like something that crept in the first week of June.
Also, all you have to do to reproduce the behavior is:
RAStart.sh RAStop.sh
(or kill, in lieu of RAStop). No need to actually *use* RAServer for anything.
I don't believe we've seen this on Windows, but we might not, given that we usually run it as a service.
Yikes, I thought this was a 4.0 only issue, do not at first see you reported this against a 3.3 build. Okay, I will look at this right away and keep the defect up to date with status. There is another defect in Windows with the same type of java core dump that occurs after file transfer / deployment has completed and when the startProcess0 native method is invoked.
We recently fixed another issue a week or so ago in and around this code (both Java and native code sides) that might have brought this on. I will update this defect with the defect # of the other.
bugzilla_98166 might be related or this could be totally different, but just in case I'm adding a dependency on the other defect for cross-reference purposes.
Per 6/15 platform call, this defect severity is reduced (even though its a crash, it is when RAC is shutting down and is not as major) and will not be fixed for 3.3 -- it will be investigated in 4.0 though to get a handle on what is really failing.
A readme defect will be opened for 3.3 so as to not alarm end-users when this expected SEGV occurs.
[ sizing = 1 day ]
I will verify if this is still the case in TPTP 4.1 -- there were some changes made in the way RAC allocates and de-allocates memory in certain situations that fixed another crash-bug like this.
I am no longer able to reproduce this using RHEL 3.0 with the latest TPTP 4.1 i2 bits. Please re-open if the problem still exists for you in 4.1 or comes back. Thanks.
Fixed indirectly. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [refactoring] Move Member Type to New File destroys variable declarations

Lines.Line: - When extracting a variable declaration fragment to a new field declaration,
it correctly copies all annotations and modifiers (except visibility). It uses
ModifierRewrite afterwards to set the visibility to the desired flag value
- In case that all fragments have been rewritten, a spurious field declaration
remained in the code, yielding compile errors. This empty field declaration is
now removed as well.
+1 for RC3.

Bug.Summery: Suboptimal code in org.eclipse.uml2.internal.operation
Bug.WithStack:
Many of the classes in this package make repeated calls to the same function rather than caching the value in a local variable.
A particulary bad example is OperationOperations.isConsistentWith which calls operation.getFormalParameters() 2p+1 and op.getReturnResults() p+1 times when the operations have p parameters. Likewise operation.getReturnResults() and op.getReturnResults() are called 2r+1 and r+1 times respectively when there are r return results. The changes have been committed to CVS. The changes are available in build 1.1RC2. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: ScalableLayeredPane does not use ScaledGraphics
Bug.WithStack: There seem to be some severe problems with ScalableRootEditPart in mirrored mode. I noticed several problems when I changed the logic example's root editpart to ScalableRootEditPart from ScalableFreeformRootEditPart (and LogicDiagramEditPart's figure's layout to XYLayout). Figures are painting at the wrong location (as if they are not mirrored). The marquee rectangle does weird things as well. The symptoms are much like those described in bug 99564. However, advanced graphics is not enabled. Forgot to mention that the flow example, which also uses the ScalableRootEditPart, is not having these problems in mirrored mode. Okay, so apparently, somewhere along the line advanced graphics is being enabled, although I don't think it's explicitly being set anywhere. Most likely another SWT bug. I'll dig deeper later. Found the problem. ScalableLayeredPane is not using ScaledGraphics and is setting the scale directly on SWTGraphics. As a result, advanced graphics is being initialized (and transform's being set). However, even that should work. So that perhaps is a bug in SWTGraphics. Pratik, ScaledGraphics must be used to avoid requiring advanced graphics support. I mistakingly released this change when fixing another bug in ScalableLayeredPane. We need another RC2 to correct this. I suppose we can call in RC2a? BTW, you can't swap the root editpart without also changing the contents figure and layout manager. I assume you did this as well and still saw problems? The remaining problem is a dupe of 99564. I've updated the summary of this bug and am marking it fixed.
